spans.text: Fresh Hokkaido potatoes on sale! Fresh Hokkaido potatoes on sale!

Taki Shiina dragged her basket towards the shelf where the salesperson was shouting, with some effort. The amount of fruits and vegetables in the basket already far exceeded the consumption of a single person in a day or two, but for the current Taki Shiina, it was far from enough.
(Hokkaido potatoes aside... this has nothing to do with fresh, does it?)

Of course, she couldn't say this directly, but the potatoes on the shelf, which are supposed to be a storable food, had a slight bluish tint on their skin, indicating that the toxins inside were reaching a dangerous level.
(Can't take this, even if it's from Hokkaido.)
Life common sense faithfully reminded her as usual, but the part of her brain responsible for crisis response seemed to have other ideas.
(If I'm going to die when the countdown ends, doesn't that mean I won't die before that?)
She picked up the blueish potato, and the scene of herself entering the hospital again due to food poisoning appeared in her mind.
(The countdown isn't a reasonable reason to end my life early. I should be good to myself.)

(But if I'm going to be good to myself... why am I stocking up on vegetables here? There are several restaurants that Anon explored during her livestream that looked tempting but I haven't tried yet...)
(But they're not exactly close, and spending most of the day traveling back and forth just for a meal... no, I have things to do.)
(But having things to do doesn't conflict with choosing good ingredients, and I should buy some good ingredients at this point anyway. Am I saving money for my will...?)
(Tch, speaking of wills...)
The voices grew louder, and she shook her head irritably.
After the top layer of potatoes was taken away, the fresh potatoes at the bottom were revealed, and she put a few of the better-looking ones into the basket.
(There are so many energy jellies and coffee in the basket, preparing these potatoes is enough.)
Taki Shiina nodded in her heart, but her eyes couldn't help but fall on the blue potato.
(Even potatoes that are about to sprout have higher levels of solanine than usual, I really can't eat it.)
(…The toxin that brings death and the sprout that brings life can actually coexist.)
She lowered her head and looked at her chest.
(Just like this heart that will stop working in a few days, it's still supporting my body with a bizarre rhythm.)
The approach of death may have really changed her a lot, at least the usual Taki Shiina would not buy a potato that is about to sprout after thinking about it for a long time.
(Take it, just as a souvenir.)
She tried to place it gently on top, but this was the limit for a full basket, and when she carefully tried to pick up the basket and stand up, they still slipped to the ground uncooperatively.
Tch.
The meaningless waste of time made her a little annoyed. Just as she was about to put down the basket and squat down, the potato was picked up by another hand.
She heard a familiar voice.
Need some help?
Taki?
Tomori?
Yes, Tomori Takamatsu.

Her schedule is healthy enough to wake up early to buy groceries while getting enough sleep, and she, who usually buys ingredients for the next day when she gets off work, actually stumbled into her healthy cycle because of "buying enough food before death".
This absurd contrast made Taki want to run away, but Tomori had obviously noticed this guy who was overwhelmed by the things she had bought before she could act.
Tomori's eyes focused on the basket in Taki's hand, the weight pressing a red mark on the other's hand.
So many vegetables... are you having a party?
Ah... no, not really.
I'm planning to stock up on more food lately, so I can come to the supermarket less often.
Tomori Takamatsu didn't ask why. She had more important questions.
Is Taki usually eating like this at home?
Tomori picked up a potato, the slightly blueish dent facing Taki like an eye, with life gestating inside.
You can't keep potatoes like this for so long, it's not good for your health!
Taki came to buy groceries herself this morning, so she should be free, right? Why don't I cook you a meal?
Eh?!
Hmm... I guess so.
I want to try to cook for everyone. I have to learn some new dishes and practice.
Yes, that's right, that's why I bought so much.
The ramen Rikki made before... was delicious!
If Taki learns a new dish, can we all try it first?
Eh? No!
Tomori looked a little frustrated.
What I mean is, I'm not confident in my cooking skills yet.
I'm a little embarrassed to make it for everyone before I'm sure it's okay.
If Tomori doesn't mind... can I make a portion for Tomori to try first?
Her eyes lit up again.
Despite making a promise to cook, Taki had no idea what to make.
(Tomori only has a carton of eggs and a few bottles of milk.)
(I have... uh. Potatoes, carrots, bell peppers...)
(It doesn't matter if I eat it myself, but it doesn't seem presentable to cook.)
(I should buy some more ingredients.)
Twenty minutes ago, when Taki made this decision, she absolutely didn't expect what she was about to face.
The vegetables were quickly taken care of, mushrooms, greens, eggplant... plus the few things she had bought before, it was comprehensive enough in terms of color and nutrition.
But what about the meat?
Making meat dishes is not a problem for Taki, she has a large cookbook full of various recipes. But in the situation of eating with Tomori, these recipes must be carefully reviewed again.
Because she still vividly remembered Tomori's slightly frowning, sad expression when she saw the caviar sushi a long time ago.
(I must never let this happen again.)
She looked at the surrounding shelves, secretly calculating in her mind.
She looked at the mackerel she often buys, the meat is tender, and it's suitable for salt-grilled or simmered in soy sauce.
(I remember Tomori went to the aquarium last week, would she mind eating fish...?)
(Let's look at something else.)
She looked at the beef lying on the shelf. The meat was evenly colored, rebounded quickly, and the slight fishy smell was showing her how fresh this piece of beef was.
The Angus cow on the shelf illustration stared with watery eyes, the eye-catching composition made it difficult to separate its image from the piece of meat in her hand.
The promotional picture, which was originally intended to showcase the meat variety, became the last line of defense to prevent Taki Shiina from picking it up.
(Let's look at something else.)
Of course, she couldn't pick anything like this. Every ingredient in the fresh food section seemed to have the potential to trigger Tomori's thoughts on life.
The two walked to the end of the fresh food section, and nothing else had been added to the basket. The almost stagnant shopping progress finally made her start to reflect.
(Am I worrying too much? I haven't been this concerned during group dinners these past few years...)
(And since it's for Tomori to eat, let's give her the right to decide.)
Tomori, fish or beef, which do you prefer?
...Or anything else is fine!
She stood a little guiltily between Tomori and the beef shelf, feeling the cow in the illustration behind her condemning her favoritism with its eyes.
I'm fine with anything.
Tomori gave the questioner the answer they were most afraid to hear at this time, and at the same time picked up a small basket of shellfish that she couldn't name.
This is delicious for stewing, I want to make stew when I don't know how to write the story, the simmering soup is very healing.
The cicada shell I found in the park before didn't help the development of that fairy tale either.
The publisher recently commissioned a fairy tale about cicadas, and I've thought about it for a long time and only came up with a rough idea, and I'm still not sure about the plot.
If Taki has any ideas, be sure to tell me.
As for other ingredients, Taki can choose whatever she likes.
Ah? Ah. Okay.
The shells were still dripping wet, and she helped Tomori open the plastic bag. The weight in her hands increased a lot with a crash, but she felt a kind of unspeakable relaxation and emptiness.
Of course, Tomori can choose what she wants to eat, and her worries were too much.
(Stew made when you can't write a story...)
She could hardly imagine what else was in the pot besides shellfish.
The small stew pot is the tip of the iceberg floating on the water, and Tomori's solitary life that she has become accustomed to is lurking under the water, crashing the ship full of concern.
She had only heard a little about the story that was troubling Tomori - a fairy tale, about cicadas. Where is it that she can't continue? Where can she try to help?
Many questions could not see the answers as the distance grew, and only a feeling of sadness remained between the blurred distances.

But this thought only lasted for a moment. Things developed too quickly, whether it was their maturity or the countdown on her head seemed to have only happened recently, and the accompanying sadness had not yet formed and was scattered by the wind that was rushing backwards.
It took more effort to lift the basket than before, and it was only slightly better after Tomori came over to take some of the bags. She finally checked the ingredients she wanted to buy.
Let's go home, Tomori.
